awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: FoMR: Taming the Instruction Bottleneck in Modern Datacenter Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Data centers are the power plants that drive the digital economy. These warehouses filled with acres of computers, operated by the likes of Google, Facebook and Amazon, run the websites and apps that we use every day. Yet, as vast as these computing resources are, the amount of code they are tasked with running is larger still and growing at around 20% each year. This project will explore new hardware and software mechanisms to allow large data center programs to better fit within their limited computing resources, to improve data center program performance and energy efficiency, and reduce the toll that power-hungry data centers take on our planet.

This project will unfold in three stages. The first stage will leverage new hardware mechanisms for profiling program execution, to obtain an accurate picture of how a data center program is running at the hardware level. The second stage will use that profiling information to adjust the code of the program at runtime to make better use of on-chip caches. The third stage will use the profiling information from the first stage, integrated with new hardware support for code prefetching and code-aware cache replacement, to drive cache utilization even higher than in stage two. Taken together, these optimizations will accelerate data center programs and improve data center energy efficiency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing hardware and software co-optimizations tailored for modern data center systems, addressing both their growing complexity and the need for efficient performance. The project leveraged a key observation: modern data center operators constantly monitor software properties, such as runtime overheads and causes of slowdowns, to facilitate continuous optimization of both hardware and software. By building on this insight, the project successfully met all the goals outlined in its original proposal.

A significant achievement of this project was the advancement of performance monitoring techniques, enabling deeper and more nuanced insights into the behavior of data center software than previously possible. These insights formed the foundation for a range of hardware optimization strategies aimed at improving system performance. Notably, these hardware optimizations were seamlessly managed through an extensible and agile software interface, ensuring adaptability to various workloads. The project also demonstrated how insights from production software executions could be harnessed to fine-tune hardware optimizations in a targeted manner, leading to enhanced system performance.

In addition, the project developed innovative online optimization techniques designed to dynamically adapt to changing application workloads. These techniques allowed for real-time adjustments, ensuring that software remained optimized even as application dynamics evolved over time. This adaptive approach significantly enhanced the overall efficiency and responsiveness of the data center systems.

The project's impact extends beyond technical advancements. It has produced multiple award-winning research papers, contributing to the academic and professional communities. The students trained through the project have gone on to achieve remarkable successes, including winning ACM Student Research Competitions. Many have joined prestigious graduate programs, while others are now employed by leading technology firms as researchers or serving as faculty members at top universities. The project's broader impact lies not only in its technological and intellectual contributions but also in the skilled professionals it has cultivated for the future of computing.
